guide.introduction: This is a ridiculously easy way to build a parabolic microphone using dollar store items. You’ll attract lots of attention walking around in public with this rig. I usually welcome the inquiries, and let people listen to what I’m doing. Kids especially love it.
guide.introduction_rendered:
This is a ridiculously easy way to build a parabolic microphone using dollar store items. You’ll attract lots of attention walking around in public with this rig. I usually welcome the inquiries, and let people listen to what I’m doing. Kids especially love it.

Relevant parts
  • Zip ties
  • Gaffer’s tape
  • Umbrella hat
  • Paint roller handle
  • Microphone
Tools
  • File
  • Hammer
  • Hobby knife
  • Laser pointer
  • Permanent marker
  • Razor saw
  • Reamer
  • Wire cutters

parts.notes: I used RadioShack's discontinued Stereo Hands-Free Tie-Pin Microphone (#33-3028), but any decent small microphone will work. Dollar store purists can instead use earbud headphones as a microphone.

lines.text: Use wire cutters to snip away the 4 plastic holders that connect the hat’s umbrella to its headband.
lines.text_raw: Use wire cutters to snip away the 4 plastic holders that connect the hat’s umbrella to its headband.

lines.text: Slice the top of the plastic knob off the top of the umbrella, and clean up the hole with a knife or reamer.
lines.text_raw: Slice the top of the plastic knob off the top of the umbrella, and clean up the hole with a knife or reamer.

lines.text: Cover 1 gore of the umbrella near the center with a trapezoidal piece of the gaffer’s tape. Cut a small X-shaped incision through the tape and umbrella; this will be the reinforced hole that the microphone wire will pass through.
lines.text_raw: Cover 1 gore of the umbrella near the center with a trapezoidal piece of the gaffer’s tape. Cut a small X-shaped incision through the tape and umbrella; this will be the reinforced hole that the microphone wire will pass through.

lines.text: Remove the paint roller’s plastic caps and wire frame. Push the shaft through the hole in the top of the umbrella, so that it protrudes 6" underneath. Leave ½" of clearance between the outer surface of the umbrella and the bend of the handle.
lines.text_raw: Remove the paint roller’s plastic caps and wire frame. Push the shaft through the hole in the top of the umbrella, so that it protrudes 6" underneath. Leave ½" of clearance between the outer surface of the umbrella and the bend of the handle.

lines.text: Just above the umbrella’s top knob, wrap a length of tape around the shaft and ring it with a cable tie pulled tight. Wrap the the shaft with more tape, to provide a gripping surface for the microphone.
lines.text_raw: Just above the umbrella’s top knob, wrap a length of tape around the shaft and ring it with a cable tie pulled tight. Wrap the the shaft with more tape, to provide a gripping surface for the microphone.

lines.text: Clip the mic to the shaft and thread the cable through the X hole. Secure the cable with cable ties.
lines.text_raw: Clip the mic to the shaft and thread the cable through the X hole. Secure the cable with cable ties.

lines.text: You want to place the microphone at the focal point of the reflector, but realize that this is a plastic umbrella, not a perfect parabola. So this “point” will be more of a semifocal blur. Here are 3 ways to position the mic, in decreasing order of complexity:
lines.text_raw: You want to place the microphone at the focal point of the reflector, but realize that this is a plastic umbrella, not a perfect parabola. So this “point” will be more of a semifocal blur. Here are 3 ways to position the mic, in decreasing order of complexity:

lines.text: Point a laser at different points on the inside of the umbrella from a distance of about 20 feet directly in front of the unit. Mark where it reflects onto the shaft to find the general region of focus.
lines.text_raw: Point a laser at different points on the inside of the umbrella from a distance of about 20 feet directly in front of the unit. Mark where it reflects onto the shaft to find the general region of focus.

lines.text: Plug the mic into a recording device, put on some headphones, and point it toward a ticking clock some distance away. Move the microphone along the shaft until you get the loudest sound.
lines.text_raw: Plug the mic into a recording device, put on some headphones, and point it toward a ticking clock some distance away. Move the microphone along the shaft until you get the loudest sound.

lines.text: Just take my word for it, and position the mic about 3" from the inside surface of the umbrella.
lines.text_raw: Just take my word for it, and position the mic about 3" from the inside surface of the umbrella.

steps.title: Take it for a test ride

lines.text: Plug your new parabolic mic into a recorder. Use headphones to monitor your work. Then point it at something interesting. You’re in for a pleasant surprise!
lines.text_raw: Plug your new parabolic mic into a recorder. Use headphones to monitor your work. Then point it at something interesting. You’re in for a pleasant surprise!

lines.text: Now try recording the same sound without the parabolic setup — forget it.
lines.text_raw: Now try recording the same sound without the parabolic setup — forget it.
